items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden will travel to Israel on Wednesday, as Hamas releases a video of a 21-year-old hostage who is asking to be returned to her family as quickly as possible. Follow live.

title.children: Joe Biden set to visit Israel on Wednesday as Hamas releases video of 21-year-old hostage

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United Nations Security Council has rejected a Russian resolution condemning violence and terrorism against civilians but making no mention of Hamas. Only four countries of the 15 UNSC members joined Russia in voting for the resolution. Four countries, including the United States, voted against it. Six countries abstained. Russia's UN ambassador, Vassily Nebenzia, had urged support for the resolution to respond to the "unprecedented exacerbation" of the situation, citing the council's inaction since the October 7 attack by Hamas. A vote on a rival resolution from Brazil that would condemn the Hamas attack was delayed. The Russian draft resolution would have called for "an immediate, durable and fully respected humanitarian cease-fire" and "strongly condemns all violence and hostilities directed against civilians and all acts of terrorism". The Brazilian draft resolution calls for "humanitarian pauses" and also "firmly condemns all violence and hostilities against civilians and all acts of terrorism". But it also "unequivocally rejects and condemns the heinous terrorist attacks by Hamas". AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UN Security Council rejects Russian resolution that does not mention Hamas

props.alt: Russia's UN Ambassador, Vassily Nebenzia, speaks at a meeting of the United Nations Security Council.

children.content: Russia's UN Ambassador, Vassily Nebenzia.
(AP)
The United Nations Security Council has rejected a Russian resolution condemning violence and terrorism against civilians but making no mention of Hamas.
Only four countries of the 15 UNSC members joined Russia in voting for the resolution. Four countries, including the United States, voted against it. Six countries abstained.

Russia's UN ambassador, Vassily Nebenzia, had urged support for the resolution to respond to the "unprecedented exacerbation" of the situation, citing the council's inaction since the October 7 attack by Hamas.
A vote on a rival resolution from Brazil that would condemn the Hamas attack was delayed.

The Russian draft resolution would have called for "an immediate, durable and fully respected humanitarian cease-fire" and "strongly condemns all violence and hostilities directed against civilians and all acts of terrorism".

The Brazilian draft resolution calls for "humanitarian pauses" and also "firmly condemns all violence and hostilities against civilians and all acts of terrorism". But it also "unequivocally rejects and condemns the heinous terrorist attacks by Hamas".
AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hamas has released a video of a young woman who is understood to be held hostage in the Gaza Strip. The video was posted on Hamas' Telegram channel and shows a young woman with a bandaged arm speaking Hebrew. She says her name is Mia Schem, she is 21 years old and from Shoham, near Tel Aviv. In the video she asks to be returned to her family as quickly as possible. A representative of the family, which was among a group of French families that appealed last week to President Emmanuel Macron to help free their missing relatives, confirmed her identity to Reuters. The Israel Defense Forces reacted to the video and said that Schem's family was notified of her abduction last week and that they are in continuous contact with them at this time. "In the video, Hamas is trying to portray itself as a humane organization, while it is a responsible for the murder and abduction of babies, women, children, and elderly," the IDF statement said. It is not known when or where the video was recorded. ABC/Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hamas releases video of 21-year-old hostage

children.content: Hamas has released a video of a young woman who is understood to be held hostage in the Gaza Strip.
The video was posted on Hamas' Telegram channel and shows a young woman with a bandaged arm speaking Hebrew. She says her name is Mia Schem, she is 21 years old and from Shoham, near Tel Aviv.

(Telegram)
In the video she asks to be returned to her family as quickly as possible.

A representative of the family, which was among a group of French families that appealed last week to President Emmanuel Macron to help free their missing relatives, confirmed her identity to Reuters.
The Israel Defense Forces reacted to the video and said that Schem's family was notified of her abduction last week and that they are in continuous contact with them at this time.

props.alt: A girl is pictured lying down as her arm is being bandaged by someone wearing gloves.

children.content: In the video an injury to Schem's arm is being bandaged
(Telegram)
"In the video, Hamas is trying to portray itself as a humane organization, while it is a responsible for the murder and abduction of babies, women, children, and elderly," the IDF statement said.
It is not known when or where the video was recorded.
ABC/Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US President Joe Biden will travel to Israel on Wednesday (local time), his Secretary of State has confirmed. Antony Blinken has been in discussions with Israeli leaders, including Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He says the US and Israel "have agreed to develop a plan that will enable humanitarian aid from donor nations and multilateral organisations to reach civilians in Gaza". "It is critical that aid begin flowing into Gaza as soon as possible," Mr Blinken says. "We share Israel's concern that Hamas may seize or destroy aid entering Gaza or otherwise prevent it from reaching the people who need it. "If Hamas in any way blocks humanitarian assistance from reaching civilians including by seizing the aid itself, we'll be the first to come to condemn it and work to prevent it from happening again. "The president very much looks forward to discussing it further when he's here on Wednesday." Other talking points flagged by Mr Blinken include the US reaffirming its commitment "that Israel has the right to defend its people from Hamas". He says Mr Biden will send a "crystal clear message" that no other nation should "take advantage of this crisis to attack Israel". "To that end, [Mr Biden] has deployed two aircraft carrier groups and other military assets to the region," Mr Blinken says. The release of hostages and a "comprehensive brief on Israel's war aims and strategy" are also on the agenda. White House National Security Council spokesman John Kirby says Mr Biden will travel to Jordan after his trip to Israel to meet with King Abdullah, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sissi and Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Joe Biden to travel to Israel on Wednesday, before meeting Palestinian President

props.alt: US President Joe Biden and Israel Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu sit on stage at the UNited Nations General Assembly.

children.content: Benjamin Netanyahu and Joe Biden at the United Nations General Assembly in September.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reports across the board confirm the first deal of the day is officially done, and Shane McAdam has had his wish granted. The Dees and Crows come to an agreement to send the forward to Melbourne, with the AFL set to confirm the trade shortly. Melbourne have traded a future second round pick to Adelaide for Shane McAdam. So this is the deal that the Demons have had on the table for quite some time, but all the while the Crows have been trying to prise Harrison Petty out of Melbourne. Once it became clear that was impossible, this rather simple deal has been done.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shane McAdam has been traded to Melbourne

children.content: (Getty Images)

Reports across the board confirm the first deal of the day is officially done, and Shane McAdam has had his wish granted. The Dees and Crows come to an agreement to send the forward to Melbourne, with the AFL set to confirm the trade shortly.
Melbourne have traded a future second round pick to Adelaide for Shane McAdam.

So this is the deal that the Demons have had on the table for quite some time, but all the while the Crows have been trying to prise Harrison Petty out of Melbourne. Once it became clear that was impossible, this rather simple deal has been done.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There is a heap on the plate still of Port Adelaide and list bost Chris Davies. At least four deals are still up in the air, and the Power aren't flinching on either of them just yet. Davies was on Trade Radio this morning, here's an upshot of what he had to say: Port Adelaide will walk Brandon Zerk-Thatcher and Esava Ratugolea to the draft if deals can't be done with Essendon and Geelong Port are reluctant to directly swap Zerk-Thatcher for Xavier Duursma Ivan Soldo has told Port he wants to join them, and Davies says the club will endeavour to make that happen — though he concedes it will be tough as Soldo is under contract at Richmond Davies believes Jordon Sweet will get to Port Adelaide by tomorrow night Davies seemed optimistic all of these deals could be done, but as you can see there is a fair bit on for our friends from Alberton.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Port Adelaide's busy two days

children.content: (Getty Images)
There is a heap on the plate still of Port Adelaide and list bost Chris Davies. At least four deals are still up in the air, and the Power aren't flinching on either of them just yet.
Davies was on Trade Radio this morning, here's an upshot of what he had to say:
Port Adelaide will walk Brandon Zerk-Thatcher and Esava Ratugolea to the draft if deals can't be done with Essendon and Geelong
Port are reluctant to directly swap Zerk-Thatcher for Xavier Duursma
Ivan Soldo has told Port he wants to join them, and Davies says the club will endeavour to make that happen — though he concedes it will be tough as Soldo is under contract at Richmond
Davies believes Jordon Sweet will get to Port Adelaide by tomorrow night
Davies seemed optimistic all of these deals could be done, but as you can see there is a fair bit on for our friends from Alberton.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lithium developer Liontown Resources entered a trading halt to raise funding for its flagship Kathleen Valley lithium project after US-based miner Albemarle abandoned a $6.6 billion buyout bid. Albemarle withdrew its indicative proposal amid "growing complexities," the companies confirmed in separate statements that came days after Hancock Prospecting, an iron ore miner controlled by Australia's richest person, Gina Rinehart, raised its stake to 19.9 per cent of Liontown. That shareholding would likely have been enough to block the Albemarle bid of $3 a share. Liontown said it had halted trade to finalise funding for Kathleen Valley in Western Australia, which is due to start producing lithium in the middle of next year. Kathleen Valley is widely regarded as one of the world's top five lithium projects, and Liontown has already signed deals to supply Ford Motor, Tesla and electric vehicle battery maker LG Energy. Liontown said last month it was well advanced in discussions with lenders to obtain at least $450 million to cover initial costs as it raised its capital cost estimate by 6 per cent to $951 million but kept its first production target. The funding package being hammered out over the next few days is expected to include an equity raising, said a person with knowledge of the matter who was not authorised to speak publicly. Liontown previously said it expected to raise debt financing from a banking syndicate and government credit agencies this year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Liontown in trading halt after Albemarle abandons its buyout

children.content: Lithium developer Liontown Resources entered a trading halt to raise funding for its flagship Kathleen Valley lithium project after US-based miner Albemarle abandoned a $6.6 billion buyout bid.

Albemarle withdrew its indicative proposal amid "growing complexities," the companies confirmed in separate statements that came days after Hancock Prospecting, an iron ore miner controlled by Australia's richest person, Gina Rinehart, raised its stake to 19.9 per cent of Liontown.
That shareholding would likely have been enough to block the Albemarle bid of $3 a share.
Liontown said it had halted trade to finalise funding for Kathleen Valley in Western Australia, which is due to start producing lithium in the middle of next year.
Kathleen Valley is widely regarded as one of the world's top five lithium projects, and Liontown has already signed deals to supply Ford Motor, Tesla and electric vehicle battery maker LG Energy.

Liontown said last month it was well advanced in discussions with lenders to obtain at least $450 million to cover initial costs as it raised its capital cost estimate by 6 per cent to $951 million but kept its first production target.
The funding package being hammered out over the next few days is expected to include an equity raising, said a person with knowledge of the matter who was not authorised to speak publicly.
Liontown previously said it expected to raise debt financing from a banking syndicate and government credit agencies this year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Economist Gareth Aird from the Commonwealth Bank has published a note on minutes of the Reserve Bank's last policy meeting. Here are some of the key points he made: Last week we categorised the November board meeting as 'live'. And we ascribed a 40% probability to a 25bp rate increase. The October board minutes confirm that the November board meeting is 'live'. Indeed, the minutes today have a slightly more hawkish tone than the September board minutes. The minutes today confirm that the board once again considered two options for monetary policy in October: raising the cash rate target by a further 25bp or holding the cash rate target steady. These two options have been considered at each of the last six board meetings. We believe the minutes today were used as a vehicle to keep markets on notice that the tightening cycle is not necessarily over given "the monthly CPI indicator suggested that progress in lowering services price inflation remained slow". The minutes reiterated the RBA's hiking bias from the September board minutes. Namely, that "some further tightening of policy may be required should inflation prove more persistent than expected." But importantly, today's minutes contained a new line, which was hawkish. Specifically that, "the board has a low tolerance for a slower return of inflation to target than currently expected." This aligns with what we stated last week. The RBA is willing to take a little longer than other central banks to return inflation to the target band to preserve as many of the gains in the labour market as is possible. But the board are not willing to let inflation sit above the target band for too long.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA minutes strike slightly more hawkish tone: CBA

children.content: Economist Gareth Aird from the Commonwealth Bank has published a note on minutes of the Reserve Bank's last policy meeting.
Here are some of the key points he made:
Last week we categorised the November board meeting as 'live'. And we ascribed a 40% probability to a 25bp rate increase.
The October board minutes confirm that the November board meeting is 'live'. Indeed, the minutes today have a slightly more hawkish tone than the September board minutes.

The minutes today confirm that the board once again considered two options for monetary policy in October: raising the cash rate target by a further 25bp or holding the cash rate target steady. These two options have been considered at each of the last six board meetings.

We believe the minutes today were used as a vehicle to keep markets on notice that the tightening cycle is not necessarily over given "the monthly CPI indicator suggested that progress in lowering services price inflation remained slow".
The minutes reiterated the RBA's hiking bias from the September board minutes. Namely, that "some further tightening of policy may be required should inflation prove more persistent than expected."
But importantly, today's minutes contained a new line, which was hawkish. Specifically that, "the board has a low tolerance for a slower return of inflation to target than currently expected."

This aligns with what we stated last week. The RBA is willing to take a little longer than other central banks to return inflation to the target band to preserve as many of the gains in the labour market as is possible. But the board are not willing to let inflation sit above the target band for too long.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares have risen in afternoon trade, led by miners after Rio Tinto reported a rise in quarterly production. The ASX 200 climbed 0.5 per cent or 34 points, to 7,061, by 12:48pm AEDT. Heavyweight miners rose 0.7 per cent, driven by a 1.6 per cent jump in Rio Tinto as the world's biggest iron ore producer reported a 1.2 per cent rise in its third-quarter iron ore shipments. Miners were also helped by an increase in iron ore futures on Monday as investor sentiment was boosted by fresh China stimulus. Financials climbed 0.8 per cent, with the big four banks rising between 0.7 per cent and 0.9 per cent. Tech stocks advanced 1.9 per cent, after the tech-heavy Nasdaq closed 1.2 per cent higher overnight. Gold stocks were up 0.2 per cent. Shares of Newcrest Mining gained 0.4 per cent even after the country's largest gold miner reported an 18.1 per cent sequential fall in quarterly gold production, hurt by maintenance shutdowns.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX still tracking higher in afternoon trade

children.content: Australian shares have risen in afternoon trade, led by miners after Rio Tinto reported a rise in quarterly production.
The ASX 200 climbed 0.5 per cent or 34 points, to 7,061, by 12:48pm AEDT.
Heavyweight miners rose 0.7 per cent, driven by a 1.6 per cent jump in Rio Tinto as the world's biggest iron ore producer reported a 1.2 per cent rise in its third-quarter iron ore shipments.
Miners were also helped by an increase in iron ore futures on Monday as investor sentiment was boosted by fresh China stimulus.
Financials climbed 0.8 per cent, with the big four banks rising between 0.7 per cent and 0.9 per cent.
Tech stocks advanced 1.9 per cent, after the tech-heavy Nasdaq closed 1.2 per cent higher overnight.

Gold stocks were up 0.2 per cent. Shares of Newcrest Mining gained 0.4 per cent even after the country's largest gold miner reported an 18.1 per cent sequential fall in quarterly gold production, hurt by maintenance shutdowns.
